message_text:
<paper>
Paper Title: Beyond Western, Educated, Industrial, Rich, and Democratic (WEIRD) Psychology: Measuring and Mapping Scales of Cultural and Psychological Distance
Paper Abstract: In this article, we present a tool and a method for measuring the psychological and cultural distance between societies and creating a distance scale with any population as the point of comparison. Because psychological data are dominated by samples drawn from Western, educated, industrialized, rich, and democratic (WEIRD) nations, and overwhelmingly, the United States, we focused on distance from the United States. We also present distance from China, the country with the largest population and second largest economy, which is a common cultural comparison. We applied the fixation index ( F ST ), a meaningful statistic in evolutionary theory, to the World Values Survey of cultural beliefs and behaviors. As the extreme WEIRDness of the literature begins to dissolve, our tool will become more useful for designing, planning, and justifying a wide range of comparative psychological projects. Our code and accompanying online application allow for comparisons between any two countries. Analyses of regional diversity reveal the relative homogeneity of the United States. Cultural distance predicts various psychological outcomes.
</paper>

<paper_classification>
"contribution" = proposes something new (method, technique, dataset, framework, benchmark, etc.)
"survey" = literature review, overview, meta-analysis, position papers (only references existing work)
</paper_classification>

<entity_types>
task      - Problem being solved (image classification, theorem proving, protein folding)
method    - Technique, algorithm, procedure (gradient descent, CRISPR, induction)
data      - Datasets, databases, benchmarks (ImageNet, MNIST, arXiv corpus)
artifact  - Pre-built: trained models, proof libraries (GPT-4, Mathlib, Cas9)
tool      - Software, instruments, platforms (PyTorch, Lean prover, microscope)
concept   - Abstract ideas, theories, frameworks (attention, category theory)
other     - Entities that don't fit above categories
</entity_types>

<relations>
uses     - Anything EXISTING that the paper uses (methods, datasets, tools, concepts, tasks)
proposes - Anything NEW/NOVEL that the paper creates or introduces

VALIDATION REQUIREMENTS:
- ALL papers MUST have at least 1 "uses" (papers always build on existing work)
- CONTRIBUTION papers MUST have at least 1 "proposes" (they must create something new)
</relations>

<output_json>
{
  "paper_type": "contribution" or "survey",
  "triples": [
    {
      "name": "Wikipedia Article Title",
      "relation": "uses|proposes",
      "entity_type": "task|method|data|artifact|tool|concept|other",
      "wikipedia_url": "https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/...",
      "relevance": "Why this matters (1 sentence)"
    }
  ]
}
</output_json>

<YOUR_TODO_LIST>
FIRST, add ALL of these to your todo list with "TodoWrite" tool:

CRITICAL: Todo content must be copied exactly as is written here, with NO CHANGES. These todos are intentionally detailed so that another LLM could read each one without any external context and understand exactly what it has to do.

1. Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as "contribution" or "survey". Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field.

2. List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation.

3. For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.

4. Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple:
   - name: Use the Wikipedia article title (e.g., "Gradient descent" not "gradient descent algorithm")
   - relation: how paper relates to entity (uses or proposes)
   - entity_type: one of task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other
   - wikipedia_url: The Wikipedia URL from search results (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/)
   - relevance: 1 sentence explaining why it matters

5. Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

6. If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.

<CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
When using WebSearch, you MUST use the allowed_domains parameter:
WebSearch(query="[your query]", allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"])

This ensures only English Wikipedia results are returned. Do NOT search without allowed_domains.
</CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
</YOUR_TODO_LIST>

Begin now.

Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.

Web search results for query: "World Values Survey"

Links: [{"title":"World Values Survey - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/World_Values_Survey"},{"title":"InglehartWelzel cultural map of the world","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/InglehartWelzel_cultural_map_of_the_world"}]

Here are the search results for the World Values Survey:

## Overview

The World Values Survey (WVS) is a global research project that explores people's values and beliefs, how they change over time, and what social and political impact they have.(no content)Since 1981 a worldwide network of social scientists have conducted representative national surveys as part of WVS.

## Origins and Development

The surveys build on the European Values Study (EVS) first carried out in 1981, which was conducted under the aegis of Jan Kerkhofs and Ruud de Moor and continues to be based in the Netherlands at the Tilburg University.(no content)Ronald Inglehart of the University of Michigan played a leading role in extending these surveys to be carried out in countries around the world.

## Applications and Research

World Values Survey data is used by the United Nation Development Programme to calculate the gender social norms index, which measures attitudes toward gender equality worldwide and was introduced in the Human Development Report starting from 2019, with four components measuring gender attitudes in politics, education, economy, and social norms related to domestic violence.

The data covers various important aspects including religious beliefs, attitudes toward social issues, and has been analyzed to create the Inglehart-Welzel cultural map, which categorizes countries based on their values along dimensions of traditional versus secular-rational values and survival versus self-expression values.

message_text:
Web search results for query: "Fixation index population genetics"

Links: [{"title":"Fixation index - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fixation_index"},{"title":"F-statistics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/F-statistics"},{"title":"Fixation (population genetics) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fixation_(population_genetics)"},{"title":"Talk:Fixation index - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Talk:Fixation_index"},{"title":"Genetic drift - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Genetic_drift"},{"title":"Fixed allele - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fixed_allele"},{"title":"Category:Population genetics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Population_genetics"},{"title":"Genetic distance - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Genetic_distance"},{"title":"Human Genetic Diversity: Lewontin's Fallacy - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human_Genetic_Diversity:_Lewontin's_Fallacy"},{"title":"Population genomics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Population_genomics"}]

Based on the search results, here's what I found about the fixation index in population genetics:

## What is the Fixation Index (FST)?

The fixation index (FST) is a measure of population differentiation due to genetic structure.(no content)Developed as a special case of Wright's F-statistics, it is one of the most commonly used statistics in population genetics.

## How It Works

It is frequently estimated from genetic polymorphism data, such as single-nucleotide polymorphisms (SNP) or microsatellites.(no content)Its values range from 0 to 1, with 0 being no differentiation and 1 being complete differentiation.

Specifically, a zero value implies complete panmixia; that is, that the two populations are interbreeding freely.(no content)A value of one implies that all genetic variation is explained by the population structure, and that the two populations do not share any genetic diversity.

## Practical Applications

For idealized models such as Wright's finite island model, FST can be used to estimate migration rates. Additionally, to quantify the genetic diversity within a population a value known as the fixation index, or FST is used. When used with Tajima's D, FST has been used to show how selection acts upon a population.

## Real-World Examples

Closely related ethnic groups, such as the Danes vs. the Dutch, or the Portuguese vs. the Spaniards show values significantly below 1%, indistinguishable from panmixia. Within Europe, the most divergent ethnic groups have been found to have values of the order of 7% (Smi vs. Sardinians).

message_text:
Web search results for query: "Psychological distance"

Links: [{"title":"Psychological distance - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Psychological_distance"},{"title":"Construal level theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Construal_level_theory"},{"title":"Distancing (psychology) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Distancing_(psychology)"},{"title":"Social distance - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Social_distance"},{"title":"Social distance corollary - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Social_distance_corollary"},{"title":"Distancing language - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Distancing_language"},{"title":"Psychic distance - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Psychic_distance"},{"title":"Universal law of generalization - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Universal_law_of_generalization"},{"title":"Fear of commitment - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fear_of_commitment"},{"title":"Similarity (psychology) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Similarity_(psychology)"}]

Here's what I found about psychological distance:

## Definition

Psychological distance refers to the relationship between someone and an event such that the greater the distance between the self and an event, the lower the mental perception of importance is for the person.(no content)Psychological distance is fundamentally egocentric, with the anchor point being the self in the present, and different interactions of the self with an object or event correlating to different levels of distance.

## Core Concept and Effects

The less important an event is perceived, the less likely one is to act on it, and this psychological distance causes behavioral differences that alter one's response to an event by changing the perception of its importance.

## Types of Psychological Distance

In Construal Level Theory (CLT), psychological distance is defined on several dimensionstemporal, spatial, social and hypothetical distance being considered most important.

- **Temporal distance**: Distance in time, where something that is temporally near is something near in time, whereas something that is temporally distant is far in time.

- **Social distance**: The more similar someone is to us, the more socially near they seem, and research has shown that an action by someone who is dissimilar to oneself is construed in more abstract terms than an action by someone who is more similar.

## Construal Level Theory

Construal Level Theory describes the relation between psychological distance and the extent to which people's thinking is abstract or concrete, with the core idea that the more distant an object is from the individual, the more abstract it will be thought of, while the closer the object is, the more concretely it will be thought of.


REMINDER: You MUST include the sources above in your response to the user using markdown hyperlinks.

Links: [{"title":"Evolution - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Evolution"},{"title":"Population genetics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Population_genetics"},{"title":"Introduction to evolution - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Introduction_to_evolution"},{"title":"Natural selection - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Natural_selection"},{"title":"History of evolutionary thought - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/History_of_evolutionary_thought"},{"title":"Modern synthesis (20th century) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Modern_synthesis_(20th_century)"},{"title":"Richard Lewontin - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Richard_Lewontin"},{"title":"Human evolutionary genetics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human_evolutionary_genetics"},{"title":"Evolutionary ecology - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Evolutionary_ecology"},{"title":"Population structure (genetics) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Population_structure_(genetics)"}]

Here's a comprehensive overview of the relationship between evolutionary theory and population genetics:

## Definition and Scope

Population genetics is a subfield of genetics that deals with genetic differences within and among populations, and is a part of evolutionary biology. Studies in this branch of biology examine such phenomena as adaptation, speciation, and population structure.

## Historical Development

In the early 20th century, competing ideas of evolution were refuted and evolution was combined with Mendelian inheritance and population genetics to give rise to modern evolutionary theory. More specifically, in the 1920s, Ronald Fisher, J.B.S. Haldane and Sewall Wright combined Darwin's theory of natural selection with statistical models of Mendelian genetics, founding the discipline of population genetics.

## Key Mechanisms

The processes that change DNA in a population include natural selection, genetic drift, mutation, and gene flow.(no content)Evolution is defined as the change in allelic frequencies within a population caused by genetic drift, gene flow between sub populations, and natural selection.

## The Modern Synthesis

In the 1920s and 1930s, the modern synthesis connected natural selection and population genetics, based on Mendelian inheritance, into a unified theory that included random genetic drift, mutation, and gene flow.(no content)This new version of evolutionary theory focused on changes in allele frequencies in population. It explained patterns observed across species in populations, through fossil transitions in palaeontology.

## Contemporary Applications

Traditionally a highly mathematical discipline, modern population genetics encompasses theoretical, laboratory, and field work. Population genetic models are used both for statistical inference from DNA sequence data and for proof/disproof of concept.

Web search results for query: "Cultural psychology cross-cultural"

Links: [{"title":"Cross-cultural psychology - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cross-cultural_psychology"},{"title":"Cultural psychology - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cultural_psychology"},{"title":"Cross-cultural studies - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cross-cultural_studies"},{"title":"Culture and positive psychology - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Culture_and_positive_psychology"},{"title":"Cross-cultural - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cross-cultural"},{"title":"Cross-cultural communication - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cross-cultural_communication"},{"title":"John W. Berry (psychologist) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/John_W._Berry_(psychologist)"},{"title":"International Association for Cross-Cultural Psychology - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/International_Association_for_Cross-Cultural_Psychology"},{"title":"Institute for International and Cross-Cultural Psychology - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Institute_for_International_and_Cross-Cultural_Psychology"},{"title":"Journal of Cross-Cultural Psychology - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Journal_of_Cross-Cultural_Psychology"}]

Here are the search results for "Cultural psychology cross-cultural":

## Key Information

**Cross-Cultural Psychology**

Cross-cultural psychology is the scientific study of human behavior and mental processes, including both their variability and invariance, under diverse cultural conditions.(no content)It seeks to extend and develop psychology by expanding research methodologies to recognize cultural variance in behavior, language, and meaning.

**Relationship to Cultural Psychology**

These are related but distinct fields. Cross-cultural psychology is differentiated from cultural psychology, which refers to the branch of psychology that holds that human behavior is strongly influenced by cultural differences, meaning that psychological phenomena can only be compared with each other across cultures to a limited extent.(no content)While cross-cultural psychologists generally use culture as a means of testing the universality of psychological processes, cultural psychologists are interested in how local cultural practices shape psychological processes differently. For example, a cross-cultural psychologist might ask whether Jean Piaget's stages of development are universal across cultures, while a cultural psychologist would be interested in how the social practices of particular cultures shape cognitive development in different ways.

**Historical Development**

While cross-cultural psychology represented only a minor area of psychology prior to WWII, it began to grow in importance during the 1960s. In 1971, the Society for Cross-Cultural Research (SCCR) was founded, and in 1972 the International Association for Cross-Cultural Psychology (IACCP) was established.

**Cultural Psychology Definition**

Cultural psychology is the study of how cultures reflect and shape their members' psychological processes. It is based on the premise that the mind and culture are inseparable and mutually constitutive, involving two propositions: that people are shaped by their culture, and that culture is shaped by its people.

Links: [{"title":"Hofstede's cultural dimensions theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hofstede's_cultural_dimensions_theory"},{"title":"Power distance - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Power_distance"},{"title":"CAGE Distance Framework - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/CAGE_Distance_Framework"},{"title":"Cultural communication - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cultural_communication"},{"title":"Chettinad Airport - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chettinad_Airport"},{"title":"Michael Muthukrishna - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Michael_Muthukrishna"},{"title":"Waterloo Bible College - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Waterloo_Bible_College"},{"title":"Blake Fitzpatrick - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Blake_Fitzpatrick"},{"title":"Nijinsky Stakes (Canada) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nijinsky_Stakes_(Canada)"},{"title":"Principled Distance - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Principled_Distance"}]

Based on the search results, here's information about cultural distance:

## Definition

Cultural distance refers to the dissimilarity in cultural norms, values, and practices between groups. It's a concept used to measure and understand differences between cultures.

## Frameworks for Measuring Cultural Distance

### Hofstede's Cultural Dimensions Theory
Hofstede's cultural dimensions theory is a framework for cross-cultural psychology that shows the effects of a society's culture on the values of its members, and how these values relate to behavior. This initial analysis identified systematic differences in national cultures on fourprimary dimensions: power distance (PDI), individualism (IDV), uncertainty avoidance (UAI) and masculinity (MAS).

### CAGE Distance Framework
The CAGE Distance Framework identifies Cultural, Administrative, Geographic and Economic differences or distances between countries that companies should address when crafting international strategies. Cultural distance affects consumers' product preferences and should be a crucial consideration for a consumer goods or media company, but it is much less important for a cement or steel business.

### Applications in Research
The concept of "cultural distance" has been introduced as a measure to quantify the differences between populations in cultural norms, values, and practices between groups, which researchers use to select culturally different samples for testing theories about human behavior.

Links: [{"title":"Hofstede's cultural dimensions theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hofstede's_cultural_dimensions_theory"},{"title":"Power distance - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Power_distance"},{"title":"CAGE Distance Framework - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/CAGE_Distance_Framework"},{"title":"Cultural communication - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cultural_communication"},{"title":"Chettinad Airport - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chettinad_Airport"},{"title":"Michael Muthukrishna - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Michael_Muthukrishna"},{"title":"Waterloo Bible College - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Waterloo_Bible_College"},{"title":"Blake Fitzpatrick - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Blake_Fitzpatrick"},{"title":"Nijinsky Stakes (Canada) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nijinsky_Stakes_(Canada)"},{"title":"Principled Distance - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Principled_Distance"}]

Based on the search results, here's information about cultural distance:

## Definition

Cultural distance refers to the dissimilarity in cultural norms, values, and practices between groups. It's a concept used to measure and understand differences between cultures.

## Frameworks for Measuring Cultural Distance

### Hofstede's Cultural Dimensions Theory
Hofstede's cultural dimensions theory is a framework for cross-cultural psychology that shows the effects of a society's culture on the values of its members, and how these values relate to behavior. This initial analysis identified systematic differences in national cultures on fourprimary dimensions: power distance (PDI), individualism (IDV), uncertainty avoidance (UAI) and masculinity (MAS).

### CAGE Distance Framework
The CAGE Distance Framework identifies Cultural, Administrative, Geographic and Economic differences or distances between countries that companies should address when crafting international strategies. Cultural distance affects consumers' product preferences and should be a crucial consideration for a consumer goods or media company, but it is much less important for a cement or steel business.

### Applications in Research
The concept of "cultural distance" has been introduced as a measure to quantify the differences between populations in cultural norms, values, and practices between groups, which researchers use to select culturally different samples for testing theories about human behavior.

Based on the search results, here's what WEIRD psychology is:

## Definition

WEIRD is a backronym that stands for "Western, Educated, Industrialized, Rich, and Democratic" and refers to the populations most commonly tapped for psychological and behavioral research.

## Origins and Purpose

Joseph Henrich's research has documented psychological differences across populations and argues that the most commonly used participants in psychological and behavioral research are not only a single type of population within a global spectrum, but that they are particularly psychologically peculiar.(no content)Henrich and his collaborators dubbed these populations as "WEIRD" to raise consciousness of this issue among researchers.

## Key Concern

Samples in psychology often rely on college students and Western, Educated, Industrialized, Rich and Democratic (WEIRD) populations. This is problematic because there has been repeated failure to replicate Western psychology laboratory findings in non-Western settings, and a major goal of cultural psychology is to have many and varied cultures contribute to basic psychological theories so they become more relevant to all human behaviors, not just Western ones.

## Related Work

Joseph Henrich wrote a 2020 book titled "The WEIRDest People in the World: How the West Became Psychologically Peculiar and Particularly Prosperous" that aims to explain history and psychological variation using approaches from cultural evolution and evolutionary psychology.

message_text:
1. [completed] Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as "contribution" or "survey". Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field.

2. [completed] List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation.

3. [completed] For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.

4. [completed] Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple: name: Use the Wikipedia article title (e.g., "Gradient descent" not "gradient descent algorithm"), relation: how paper relates to entity (uses or proposes), entity_type: one of task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other, wikipedia_url: The Wikipedia URL from search results (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/), relevance: 1 sentence explaining why it matters

5. [completed] Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

6. [completed] If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.

message_text:
Excellent! All tasks have been completed successfully. Here's a summary of what was accomplished:

## Summary

I've successfully analyzed the paper "Beyond Western, Educated, Industrial, Rich, and Democratic (WEIRD) Psychology: Measuring and Mapping Scales of Cultural and Psychological Distance" and created a comprehensive triples output file.

**Paper Classification:** **Contribution** - The paper proposes new methods and tools for measuring psychological and cultural distance between societies.

**Identified Triples (6 total):**

1. **World Values Survey** (data, uses) - Dataset of cultural beliefs and behaviors used for the analysis
2. **Fixation index** (method, uses) - Population genetics statistic applied to cultural data
3. **Psychological distance** (concept, proposes) - New method for measuring psychological distance between societies
4. **Cross-cultural psychology** (concept, uses) - Addresses WEIRD bias in the field
5. **Hofstede's cultural dimensions theory** (concept, uses) - Theoretical framework for understanding cultural differences
6. **The WEIRDest People in the World** (concept, uses) - Directly addresses documented WEIRD bias in research

All Wikipedia URLs have been verified and the validation script passed successfully. The output file is ready for use.

Sources:
- [World Values Survey](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/World_Values_Survey)
- [Fixation index](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fixation_index)
- [Psychological distance](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Psychological_distance)
- [Cross-cultural psychology](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cross-cultural_psychology)
- [Hofstede's cultural dimensions theory](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hofstede's_cultural_dimensions_theory)
- [The WEIRDest People in the World](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_WEIRDest_People_in_the_World)
